unnormalised: Diwali, also known as the Festival of Lights, is a significant 5-day festival in India. This year, Diwali falls on Nov 12th, 2024. The festivities begin on Dhanteras, which is 2 days before Diwali. Many families prepone their regular activities to better accommodate the Diwali timeframe.
normalised: Diwali, also known as the Festival of Lights, is a significant five day festival in India. This year, Diwali falls on November twelfth, two thousand and twenty four. The festivities begin on Dhanteras, which is two days before Diwali. Many families prepone their regular activities to better accommodate the Diwali timeframe.

unnormalised: Dhanteras, occurring on 11/10/2024, marks the beginning of the Diwali celebrations. People often buy gold and silver articles as a symbol of good luck. The next day, 11/11/2024, is Choti Diwali, also known as Naraka Chaturdashi.
normalised: Dhanteras, occurring on tenth November, two thousand and twenty four, marks the beginning of the Diwali celebrations. People often buy gold and silver articles as a symbol of good luck. The next day, eleventh November, two thousand and twenty four, is Choti Diwali, also known as Naraka Chaturdashi.

unnormalised: Diwali itself, also called Lakshmi Puja, is celebrated on 12/11/2024. Families perform pujas to Goddess Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth and prosperity, typically between 6:00 PM and 8:00 PM. Houses are decorated with diyas (oil lamps) and rangolis (colorful designs).
normalised: Diwali itself, also called Lakshmi Puja, is celebrated on twelfth November, two thousand and twenty four. Families perform pujas to Goddess Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth and prosperity, typically between six zero zero P-M and eight zero zero P-M. Houses are decorated with diyas (oil lamps) and rangolis (colorful designs).

unnormalised: The day after Diwali, 13/11/2024, is Govardhan Puja. It commemorates the day Lord Krishna lifted Govardhan Hill to protect the villagers from torrential rains. Many people create a small hillock made of cow dung and worship it.
normalised: The day after Diwali, thirteenth November, two thousand and twenty four, is Govardhan Puja. It commemorates the day Lord Krishna lifted Govardhan Hill to protect the villagers from torrential rains. Many people create a small hillock made of cow dung and worship it.

unnormalised: Bhai Dooj falls on 14/11/2024. This festival celebrates the bond between brothers and sisters. Sisters pray for their brothers' long lives and prosperity. Bhai Dooj usually takes place from 1:30 PM to 3:30 PM, which is considered an auspicious time.
normalised: Bhai Dooj falls on fourteenth November, two thousand and twenty four. This festival celebrates the bond between brothers and sisters. Sisters pray for their brothers' long lives and prosperity. Bhai Dooj usually takes place from one thirty P-M to three thirty P-M, which is considered an auspicious time.

unnormalised: While the exact timings and observances can vary regionally, these 5 days are celebrated with great enthusiasm across India. Keep in mind that there are sometimes conflicting dates listed, but these reflect variations from different regions of India. Diwali’s symbolism and themes of victory, hope, and prosperity are timeless.
